Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Analysis of Rapid Cultural Change

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
People have multiple overlapping and intersecting identities including their biology, health and socioeconomic status, that define who they are and how they interact with others. These identities can be used to empower or disenfranchise individuals and communities based on social milieu. Disruptions to social environments initiated by changing demographics (migration) or political upheaval can transform the social significance of these identities. Within this broad context and under the supervision of Dr. Margaret Judd of the University of Pittsburgh, doctoral candidate Deborah Neidich will investigate the impact of human mobility on identity construction following a period sociopolitical turmoil. This project contributes to the body of research regarding material signifiers of identity and the relationship between cultural processes and biology; it may also point to the origins of historically recognized groups that emerged during sociopolitical change. This is particularly important as it may serve as a historical analogy to modern sociopolitical issues regarding contemporary migration by highlighting a diverse history that was forged by migrations and migrants. The information obtained through this research will be the foundation for Ms Neidich’s dissertation and available electronically as well as in a series of academic publications.

Ms. Neidich will use a range of sources including the skeletal biological profile (age, sex, and chemical markers of mobility) and skeletal evidence for biological stress and diet. Stable isotope analysis of carbon and nitrogen adds a dietary signature, while grave goods analysis provides information concerning status and gender. Combined, the data can identify salient social categories to answer the following three questions: (1) Which aspects of a person’s identity were important for a community to mark at a person’s burial? (2) Were social disparities expressed as differences in health, trauma and diet, related to identity in the past? (3) Was there a shift in the perception of these categories during political change and periods of stability? This work will identify transitions in identity and mobility over an extended period of time. The project will assess patterns of change in demography, health, diet and grave good distribution to evaluate how identities were expressed prior to and transformed.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project, ?Doctoral Dissertation Improvement Grant: Analysis of Rapid Cultural Change? investigated identity formation in the Late Antique (300-470 CE) and Migration (ca. 470-700 CE) Periods of Bavaria, Germany. The project has produced several outcomes in its investigation of the impacts of mobility, socioeconomics, health, and gender on identity after the fall of the Roman Empire in Early Medieval Germany. This research addresses rapid behavioral adaptations undertaken by communities who had lived on the periphery of Roman influence as they adjusted to new post-Roman political, economic, and disease conditions.

During the funded period Deborah L. Neidich spent nearly five months in Germany collecting data from 218 skeletonized individuals from the Altenerding necropolis curated at the Staatssammlung f?r Anthropologie und Pal?eonatomie, M?nchen (SAPM). To answer her research questions, she collected a range of data including skeletal biological profile (age, sex, and strontium isotope markers of mobility), skeletal markers of stress and trauma, dietary signatures from stable carbon and nitrogen isotope analysis, and radiocarbon dates. New radiocarbon dates were collected from the ribs of ten individuals which provided new dates for the latter use of the site, and for individuals who were buried without grave goods. Strontium samples were taken from the ribs of 40 individuals as a proxy for human mobility; carbon and nitrogen samples were taken from the ribs of 30 individuals to assess dietary patterns. Grave good analysis was also undertaken to gather information concerning gender and socioeconomic status.

Key outcomes of this project suggest that individual identities are contingent on multiple integrated biological and socioeconomic factors, and that temporal shifts in salient markers of a person?s identity are likely the result of local social and economic influences as opposed to changes in broader political affiliation. This was demonstrated by the fact that the periods immediately surrounding and following Roman occupation of southern Germany displayed relatively high stability in diet [δ13C= -20.3 to -16.8?, δ15N = 7.9 to11.4?], markers of health and the inclusion of burial items. The most dramatic changes occurred roughly 200 years after Roman occupation ended, during the Younger Merovingian period (600-670 CE) and are primarily associated with changing economic focuses of local communities, and the introduction of new agricultural technologies into the region as well as recovery from the impacts of the Plague of Justinian (ca. 541 CE).

The role of migration in identity studies is also highlighted here. At Altenerding, most migrants were female, suggesting that residence patterns emphasize male locality. After migrants settled in southern Germany, migrants appear (at least in death) integrated into local communities, as they have similar dietary (e.g., consumption of C4 plants [wheat, barley, etc.], consumption of terrestrial animal meat and secondary products), health, and grave inclusion patterns as their local contemporaries. All migrants identified in this sample were buried with grave goods (e.g., weapons, jewelry, tools, etc.) suggesting that moving long distances required some level of social and/or economic wealth which could support their move and sustain them in their adopted communities. Most migrants from Altenerding were identified in previous research but one new migrant, a young female from the Younger Merovingian Period, was found.

This project highlights the complexity of individual and community identities and how those aspects of a person?s identity impacted their health. This project is the result of international collaborative partnerships with SAPM, Ludwig Maximillian University of Munich, University of Bern, Erding Museum and the descendent community of Erding. Results of this project will be presented in academic publications and presentations as well as a series of talks offered to the general public hosted by the Erding Museum. This project is a multi-disciplinary investigation of salvage-excavated materials and emphasizes the value of rescued materials for archaeological research despite the limitations of excavation practices associated with these resources. Additionally, this is the first synthetic analysis of adult burials from Altenerding using standard bioarchaeological methods.
